Hi Mike,

> In my opinion, developers should not write the web page navigation
> and contents tests.  This is not unit testing.  This is functional
> testing that should be done by the QA team.  Although I admit the
> line between unit and functional testing is sometimes blurry.

    But in the situation described by Paul, there is no QA Staff available
to do so. Do I get it right that in your opinion in such a situations there
is no need for functional testing?

> With Front Controller you can gut all of your business logic out of
> your servlets and JSPs.  Your business logic would be contained in
> separate classes which can be unit tested.
> Mike
>

    IMHO, even if I am going the model 2 way and my business logic layer is
doing fine, the presentation layer can break and bugs in the integration are
rather likely to be coded.

    IMHO, you should do functional testing. Yes, I had the same problem with
HttpUnit when using it for unit tests. But for functional testing I believe
it to be a great help and a wonderful tool (Thank you Russel Gold et al.).
Keeping the functional tests up with other tools (even with graphical tools
for none programmers) will also be a pain, if design changes very rapidly.

    IMHO, if  QA staff cannot write the functional tests, it will at least
be in the position to describe the functional tests. Thus if I am up to
integrating my stuff - I tend to think of writing the controler of model 2
as integration - I write down the stories related to my integration. If
these functional tests go fine, I am done with integrating. If the design is
about to change in a way, that it will affect my test code, I tell
management about this. No one ever stated, that changes in requirements or
design come for free. Thus I do testing with HttpUnit, but on functional
level and not unit level. And using it this way, the pain my collegues and I
had with keeping the tests up is quite okay. And if you are straight with
management about the costs of change, unnecessary changes in design (the
typical: "Oh, let's do that, because at the time I, the manager or marketing
person, believe it to be cool.") are not very likely.

Toyin
